title: Carbon Pricing and Resale in Emission Trading Systems
abstract:
Secondary markets and resale are integral components of all emission trading
systems. Despite the justification for these secondary trades, such as
unpredictable demand, they may encourage speculation and result in the
misallocation of permits. In this paper, our aim is to underscore the
importance of efficiency in the initial allocation mechanism and to explore how
concerns leading to the establishment of secondary markets, such as uncertain
demand, can be addressed through alternative means, such as frequent auctions.
We demonstrate that the existence of a secondary market could lead to higher
untruthful bids in the auction, further encouraging speculation and the
accumulation of rent. Our results suggest that an inefficient initial
allocation could enable speculators with no use value for the permits to bid in
the auction and subsequently earn rents in secondary markets by trading these
permits. Even if the secondary market operates efficiently, the resulting rent,
which represents a potential loss of auction revenue, cannot be overlooked.
